(JLWH. N<sup>o</sup>. 75)
On
the Barometer
<u>by J. F. Daniels F. R. S.</u>
Read Jan 26, 1826

In a paper upon the Barometer, which
I had the honour of presenting to
the Royal Society in November 1824,
I submitted to their consideration
some experiments and observations
from which I thought myself 
entitled to infer that Barometers
of the usual construction, however
carefully made, must be liable 
to a gradual deterioration from
the slow insinuation of air
between the mercury & the [tube?].
It was a subject of [?] with
me, at the time, that I had not
been able to find any [registers?],
except that of the Royal Society
to the [?], which
continued for a sufficient length

<s>Record Nov 16</s>
<s>1825 H. D.</s>
<u>Archives</u>
unpub

(JLWH. N<sup>o</sup>. 75)
On
the Barometer
<u>by J. F. Daniels F. R. S.</u>
Read Jan 26, 1826

In a paper upon the Barometer, which
I had the honour of presenting to
the Royal Society in November 1824,
I submitted to their consideration
some experiments and observations
from which I thought myself 
entitled to infer that Barometers
of the usual construction, however
carefully made, must be liable 
to a gradual deterioration from
the slow insinuation of air
between the mercury & the tube.
It was a subject of regret with
me, at the time, that I had not
been able to find any registers,
except that of the Royal Society
to the year 1806, which had been 
continued for a sufficient length
